Get the Reddit app
The biggest and best place on the internet for fantasy football discussion, strategy, and advice.

Home of AMAugust where the biggest names in the industry answer your questions.
NFL 2024: The Changing Landscape of Passing and Rushing Trends Over the Last Decade
When there are 12 QBs with 10 or more rushes through two weeks, things get wonky. And to kick off this season, two of the most athletic but not good passers were added to the statistical mix (AR and Daniels…and he’ll, so far Caleb as well). Couple that with the return of guys like fields and Watson not being able to complete a pass, and things are off to a rocky start.
I’d be curious to see what the rb stats are on a comparative basis over the years without the QBs mucking up the data.
True, and its also only two weeks of stats, so it'll be interesting to see how things play out. Totalyards in general are trending down which, regardless of QB runs, isn't enough to make up for the lack of passing yards. All of the injuries at WR certainly won't help either.
If you actually look at the starting QB for each team this year, the lower passing stats make perfect sense. I expect this trend to continue for a while, but maybe the run rate will go down as some of the younger QBs get more acclimated and the more established QBs get in a rhythm.
We have the rookie QBs:
Bo Nix
Caleb Williams
Jayden Daniels
Year 2 QBs who didn't start all of last season, so they're almost rookies:
Anthony Richardson
Will Levis
"Established" Year 2 QBs:
Bryce Young (not for long)
Jordan Love (who played one game this year, and his backup in week 2 is not a normal starting caliber QB)
CJ Stroud (although he is only increasing passing stats for the league)
And the "transition" QBs (not the expected future of the franchise, but they have to start someone):
Jacoby Brissett (Maye)
Justin Fields (Russell Wilson preferred starter)
Sam Darnold (what will happen with McCarthy if Darnold continues to be good?)
Gardner Minshew (what is the plan?)
The thing that may normalize a bit are the more established QBs who haven't put up great numbers so far:
Joe Burrow
Jared Goff
Dak Prescott
Justin Herbert (seems like an offensive game plan switch)
Kirk Cousins (yeah?)
Aaron Rodgers
Trevor Lawrence (jury is still out...)
Matt Stafford (team is decimated, so probably not going to change soon)
Daniel Jones (hahaha)
Don't we generally have that same situation every year though?  3 rookie starting QBs doesn't seem outside the norm for the last decade.
Here is the complete dataset in a gdoc so you guys can take a closer look.
Anyone can view, post, and comment to this community

articles.title: NFL 2024: The Changing Landscape of Passing and Rushing ...
articles.summary:
### Fantasy Football Advice Summary - Recent Developments

As the 2024 NFL season progresses, fantasy football managers are navigating a landscape increasingly impacted by shifting trends in quarterback performance and injuries among key players. Here are the main developments and insights to consider:

1. **Quarterback Performance Trends**: 
   - Early statistics indicate a decline in passing touchdowns, with only 66 recorded through the first two weeks of the 2024 season, compared to 105-110 in the previous years. This downward trend suggests a growing need for managers to reconsider their quarterback strategies.
   - The integration of dual-threat quarterbacks has altered game dynamics. Notably, athletic but underskilled passers, including rookies such as Anthony Richardson and Caleb Williams, are influencing statistics that fantasy players must account for when evaluating player performances.

2. **Injuries and Impacted Players**:
   - Player injuries continue to affect fantasy outcomes significantly. For instance, Travis Etienne Jr. has scored negative fantasy points due to injury concerns, reminding managers to monitor injury reports closely as week-to-week developments can dramatically change player viability.

3. **Emerging Strategies**:
   - With lower overall passing yards and ongoing rookie transitions at the quarterback position, managers might want to pivot towards running backs and wide receivers who have shown consistency, as these roles are critical for scoring in a more run-heavy league scenario.

4. **Checklists for Drafting Decisions**:
   - Keeping an eye on the performances of established yet underperforming quarterbacks is essential. These players, such as Joe Burrow and Justin Herbert, might regain their rhythm as the season progresses, presenting potential buy-low opportunities for fantasy teams.

5. **Community Insights**:
   - Engaging with dedicated forums and discussions, notably platforms like Reddit’s fantasy football communities, can yield valuable advice, strategies, and real-time updates from industry experts and passionate fans who dissect trends and player performances closely.

By understanding these latest trends and injury impacts, fantasy football managers can make informed decisions to optimize their rosters and adapt to the evolving challenges of the 2024 season.

articles.title: Fantasy Points: Fantasy Football Projections & Rankings, Strategy ...
articles.summary:
### Fantasy Football Advice Summary (Week 7, 2024)

As we dive into Week 7 of the 2024 fantasy football season, here are the crucial updates and insights to enhance your lineup decisions:

1. **Start 'Em, Sit 'Em Recommendations**:
   - Graham Barfield's analysis provides essential stats to assist in making critical start/sit calls for your fantasy teams this week.

2. **WR/CB Matchups**:
   - Joe Dolan highlights potential shadow coverage scenarios, identifying both advantageous and challenging matchups for wide receivers and cornerbacks in Week 7. This insight is vital for optimizing player selections based on defensive matchups.

3. **Game Hub Overview**:
   - Tom Brolley presents a comprehensive Game Hub, summarizing key statistics and trends that are impacting fantasy-relevant players this week, which is crucial for strategic decisions.

4. **Trade Recommendations**:
   - John Hansen outlines players to research for trades, emphasizing those to sell high or buy low, ensuring you're making the most informed transactional choices as the season progresses.

5. **Waiver Wire Insights**:
   - Updated recommendations on the waiver wire are essential for reflating your roster ahead of Week 7, particularly for managers looking to capitalize on current trends and injuries.

6. **DFS Considerations**:
   - The DFS Early Look for Week 7 offers strategies for daily fantasy contests, making it easier for players to identify value picks and potential breakout candidates.

In summary, this week's key focus should be on upcoming player matchups, strategic trade decisions, and leveraging insights from game-related data to make the best possible lineup choices. Stay vigilant in tracking injury reports and emerging trends as the week unfolds.

otton highest snap ct of all TEs and 5th in routes run so far this season

Can’t decide between McBride or Kraft , they play each other this week.
I've Mcbride, Kraft, and Laporta. I went Kraft last week, back to Mcbride this week.
He's got a week under his belt, and continues to see great volume. He's also arguably the most talented of the three, and packers may be getting some people back.
Good morning! This weekly article focuses on tight end trends to help fantasy managers know which tight ends to target and which ones to avoid.
In this article, we’ll be looking at the top-16 players in total routes, route participation rate, total targets, target share, target rate, yards per route run, and expected half-PPR PPG in relation to where they fall in terms of their actual half-PPR PPG.
This will help us find guys who are over-achieving (hardly no one) and who are under-achieving. But it can help us find players to target.
Who are your tight ends? Who is on the waiver wire? Do you have any start/sit questions for Week 6? I’ll try to answer as many questions as possible and as always, thanks for reading!

articles.title: Tight End Trends - Fantasy Football Week 6 : r/fantasyfootball
articles.summary:
### Fantasy Football Advice Summary (Week 6)

As fantasy football season progresses into Week 6, here are the latest trends and insights that fantasy managers should consider:

1. **Tight End Landscape**: This week’s analysis focuses on tight end performance, highlighting the importance of targeting players based on their snap count, route participation, and target share. Notably, **Trey McBride** stands out with significant volume, amassing 14 targets for a 38% share in his last game. Meanwhile, **Tucker Kraft** continues to perform reliably, not scoring below 4.2 fantasy points (Half PPR) since Week 11 of last season with Jordan Love at quarterback.

2. **LaPorta and Kraft Decision-Making**: Managers are grappling with who to start between **Sam LaPorta** and Kraft, as both have drawn recent interest. There is an ongoing discussion about LaPorta's potential to 'go off' this week due to favorable matchups, making him an intriguing play despite concerns over trending performance. Trade suggestions are circulating, with some advising to package either player to strengthen other positions.

3. **Waiver Wire Strategy**: With players like **Hockenson** emerging on waivers, discussions center around strategic pick-ups to enhance team performance. Hockenson's high snap percentage places him in a favorable position for the coming weeks.

4. **Volume and Performance Assessment**: The analysis emphasizes looking for tight ends that are underperforming relative to their volume metrics. Managers are encouraged to seek opportunities based on yardage per route run and expected half-PPR points per game.

5. **Market Adjusted Trade Values**: There's an uptick in discussions regarding trade values as managers look to optimize their rosters. It’s advisable for fantasy players to stay alert to potential trade avenues, especially with respect to trending performance metrics.

Staying active in discussions and leveraging community insights (e.g., Reddit AMAs) can provide additional strategies and support for fantasy decision-making this week.
